title: Discriminative-Generative Custom Tokens for Vision-Language Models
author: Pramuditha Perera (AWS AI Labs), Matthew Trager (AWS AI Labs), Luca Zancato (AWS AI Labs), Alessandro Achille (AWS AI Labs), Stefano Soatto (AWS AI Labs)
relevance_why: The paper explores learning custom tokens that can be applied to both generative image synthesis and classification tasks, which could inform approaches for audio-visual integration and multimodal learning in Haohe Liu's research.
background: Learning new tokens to represent visual concepts using small image sets while also being effective for both generating images and recognizing concepts.
contribution: This paper introduces a unified framework for learning custom tokens for generative and discriminative tasks, demonstrating improved image generation and retrieval performance on specific datasets.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods focused either on discriminative tasks or purely generative tasks, often lacking flexibility in representation.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work combines both objectives through a novel training regime that improves compositionality with natural language, enhancing the performance of visual queries.

key_innovation: The method employs a two-component approach utilizing textual inversion and classification networks to enable custom token learning that is effective for both generation and recognition.
real_world_impact: Enhancing the retrieval and generation of visual content could have significant applications in creative industries, automation, and personalized content generation.
limitations: Challenges remain in ensuring generated images always adhere faithfully to intended concepts when composing with natural language.

new_terms.textual inversion: **Textual inversion** is a process of learning new tokens in a model to generate images of specific concepts based on a small number of images.
new_terms.Generation Aided Image Retrieval (GAIR): **GAIR** is a method that modifies queries in real time during inference to improve the image retrieval process.
